page.title: 05ROUND TOWERS
page.content: Five round towers line the coast from La Rocque to Grouville Common. They were built to defend Jersey from French attack in the late eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. These towers, which were constructed as a consequence of the French invasion that led to the Battle of Jersey in 1781, are not 'Martello' Towers in the proper sense, since true Martello Towers were built later following the pattern of a round tower at Cap Mortella in Corsica. The round towers in Grouville Bay are 36 feet high, with a base diameter of 34 feet. The walls are 8 feet thick at the base, narrowing to 6 feet at the crest. The doorway is raised above ground to make entry difficult for the enemy. Round Tower Number 4 has been added to and converted into a house.
